newsitem.title: LITHUANIA: KLAIPEDOS DUONA TO PAY NO DIVIDENDS FOR 96.
newsitem.headline: KLAIPEDOS DUONA TO PAY NO DIVIDENDS FOR 96.

text.p: Lithuania's bread and bread products producer Klaipedos Duona (Klaipeda Bread) said on Tuesday it will pay no dividends from 1996 profit.
The company reported earlier its net profit dropped to 1.66 million litas in 1996 versus 2.13 million litas a year before. The company is listed on the group A list of Vilnius bourse.
"The shareholders' meeting on Thursday decided to pay 10 percent dividends to the owners of privilege shares only," the director of Klaipedos Bread, Jonas Brozhaitis, told Reuters.
"The sum to be paid is around 50,000 litas and the rest of the profit will remain in the company to pay our credits," Brozhaitis added.

The company has taken a long-term 3.5 million litas credit from the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) in 1996 to upgrade the bakery and now has to repay annually around 500,000 litas until 2000, Brozhaitis said.
The company also leased 30 cars for bread transporting this year.
"Our company plans to boost its share capital in the second half of 1997 by 500,000 litas," Brozhaitis said.
The present share capital of the company is 3.7 million litas and assets at the end of 1996 were 13.05 million litas.
The state owns 20 percent of Klaipedos Duona and the rest is owned by the employees of the company, Brozhaitis said.
"The company has around eleven percent of the country's bread and its products market," he added.
